Rice husk-based biogenic silica-anchored Sn-Co bimetallic catalysts for cellulose hydrogenolysis: Structural regulation and mechanism study Xiaohao Liu Methodology Resources Funding acquisition Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Zibin Xia Data curation Formal analysis Writing – original draft a Rui Diao Methodology Data curation b Fenglei Qi Supervision Writing – review & editing b Ying Zhang Writing – review & editing c Peiyong Ma Supervision Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing b d a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei, Anhui 230009, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Hefei University of Technology Hefei Anhui 230009 China aSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei, Anhui 230009, China b School of Mechanical Engineering, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei, Anhui 230009, China School of Mechanical Engineering Hefei University of Technology Hefei Anhui 230009 China bSchool of Mechanical Engineering, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei, Anhui 230009, China c Department of Chemistry, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, China Department of Chemistry University of Science and Technology of China Hefei 230026 China cDepartment of Chemistry, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, China d Anhui Province Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Recycling Technology and Equipment for Mechanical and Electrical Products, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei, Anhui 230009, China Anhui Province Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Recycling Technology and Equipment for Mechanical and Electrical Products Hefei University of Technology Hefei Anhui 230009 China dAnhui Province Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Recycling Technology and Equipment for Mechanical and Electrical Products, Hefei University of Technology, Hefei, Anhui 230009, China ⁎ Corresponding author. The production of high value-added chemicals and materials from renewable biomass is significant for the sustainable development of chemical industry. Herein, rice husk-based biogenic silica-anchored Sn-Co catalysts with adjustable activity are successfully prepared for biomass valorization. By regulating the pretreatment method and carbothermal reduction temperature of catalysts, the interaction between Co, Sn and biogenic silica can be regulated, thereby regulating the catalytic activity of the catalyst for cellulose hydrogenolysis. 50.7 % yield of acetol and 63.4 % yield of C3 products can be obtained. A series of characterizations show that the hydrothermal pretreatment in CoCl2 solution promotes the combination of Co2+ and biogenic silica, which inhibits the excessive doping of Sn4+ and promotes the formation of Co3Sn2 alloy. The Sn-O-Si and Co3Sn2 species in 3Sn-5Co@RHC are the key active sites catalyzing glucose isomerization and fructose retro-aldol condensation. The intermediates experiments show that controlling the hydrolysis rate of cellulose to avoid excessive concentration of monosaccharide intermediates in the reaction system is crucial for inhibiting side reactions and improving the yield of acetol. The use of agroforestry waste-based catalytic materials for biomass conversion in this work can provide inspiration for exploiting the intrinsic characteristics of biomass to develop high value-added materials and chemicals. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Rice husk Biogenic silica Bimetals Cellulose conversion Acetol Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction The conversion of renewable biomass to high value-added chemicals and materials is an important way to meet sustainable development [1–3]. As an important component of lignocellulosic biomass, selective conversion of cellulose has attracted extensive attention [4]. A series of high value-added chemicals including ethylene glycol (EG), ethanol, lactic acid (LA) and alkanes have been successfully prepared [5–7]. In recent years, acetol, which can be used as pharmaceutical intermediates and food additives, has also been reported to be prepared from cellulose [8]. Unlike the aforementioned chemicals, the preparation of acetol requires more precise regulation of the catalytic site due to its long reaction path (Scheme 1 ), numerous side reactions, and unstable acetol product (prone to excessive hydrogenation or condensation) [9,10]. However, relevant studies are insufficient. Sn-based catalysts are the most reported catalysts for the conversion of carbohydrates to acetol and other C3 chemicals due to their suitable Lewis acid or base properties to catalyze the isomerization and retro-aldol condensation of carbohydrates. Ni-Sn/Al2O3 and Ni-Sn@C catalysts were reported for catalytic conversion of cellulose, and about 35 % yield of acetol was obtaineds. Ni-Sn bimetals can form NiSn alloys during high temperature reduction, which plays an important role in the production of acetol [11,12]. In addition, metal-support interaction is also an important means to regulate the catalyst activity. SiO2 is generally considered to be an inert support and its effect on the activity of the loaded metal is always ignored. However, in our previous work, we found that amorphous nano-silica (15±5 nm) loaded with Ni-Sn bimetals can significantly affect the electronic state of Sn to form SnOx and Snδ+ species with non-integer valence states. These species provide abundant basic sites for catalysts that efficiently catalyze glucose isomerization and retro-aldol condensation of fructose, resulting in a high yield of acetol from cellulose (∼60 %) [13,14]. However, nano-silica is not economical and environmentally friendly, and it is easy to enter organisms and endanger health [15]. Rice husk contains abundant natural silica (>20 wt%) [16]. This biogenic silica (phytolith) exhibits precise genetic control, possessing high activity and nano level delicate structure [17,18]. Currently, many efforts have been made to extract the silica as support materials for heterogeneous catalysts. Reactions such as oxidation, hydrogenation, esterification as well as biomass gasification have all been reported through this strategy [19–21]. For example, Franco et al. used the mechanochemical/microwave/calcination method to extract silica from rice husk. It was found that the extracted silica supported iron oxides showed good catalytic activity in benzyl alcohol oxidation [22]. However, extraction methods such as calcination and strong acid-base treatment can destroy the natural structure of silica and then affect its activity. It is meaningful to explore the catalytic application potential of natural non-extracted biogenic silica in rice husk. Unglaube et al., using unextracted rice husks as raw materials, prepared Ag-based catalysts by impregnating rice husks with silver nitrate solution followed by carbothermal reduction. The catalyst showed good activity and selectivity in nitro group hydrogenation [23]. However, the role of biogenic silica in catalysis was not explored. Considering that active biogenic silica is likely to strongly interact with metals, it is necessary to explore its potential for regulating the catalytic activity of catalysts. However, related studies have not been reported. In this work, rice husk-based biogenic silica-anchored Sn-Co bimetallic catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal/impregnation treatment of rice husk with Sn, Co precursors followed by carbothermal reduction. The metal-carrier and metal-metal interactions can be regulated by adjusting the metal loading mode (hydrothermal or impregnation) and sequence, thereby regulating the catalytic performance for cellulose conversion to acetol. Through a series of experiments and comparative characterization analysis, the activity of catalysts prepared by different metal loading methods and carbothermal reduction temperatures was tested, and the impact on cellulose conversion was explored. Experiment section Reagents Rice husk was collected from Shouxian County, Anhui Province, China. Cellulose powder (<25 μm), acetol, and 1‑hydroxy-2-butanone (HB) were purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd.; CoCl2·6H2O, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, SnCl4·5H2O, SnCl2·2H2O, glucose, fructose, lactic acid (LA), ethylene glycol (EG), and 1,2- propylene glycol(1,2-PG) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Catalyst preparation 5Co@RHC preparation process is as follows: 5 g of rice husk (> 80 mesh) was added to a 50 mL aqueous solution containing 1.06 g of CoCl2·6H2O (5 wt% Co loading relative to rice husk). The mixture was then poured into a 100 mL hydrothermal kettle and subjected to hydrothermal treatment for 12 h at 200 °C. After cooling to room temperature, the solvent water was removed by using a rotary steam dryer and dried in an oven at 105 °C overnight. When the tube furnace was heated to 300 °C, the dried powder was added. Subsequently, the temperature was heated (1 °C /min) to 600 °C and maintained at 600 °C for 2 h. The entire pyrolysis process was carried out in a N2 flow (100 mL/min). After cooling to room temperature, the solid product was purged with 1 % O2/N2 for 30 min. The obtained sample is named as 5Co@RHC. The synthesis of 5Co@RHC(Co(NO3)2) is also performed according to the method above, but CoCl2·6H2O is replaced by Co(NO3)2·6H2O. xSn-5Co@RHC preparation process is as follows: 5 g of rice husk (> 80 mesh) was added to a 50 mL aqueous solution containing 1.06 g of CoCl2·6H2O (5 wt% Co loading relative to rice husk). After cooling down to room temperature, the mixture was transferred to a round-bottomed flask. A certain amount of SnCl4·5H2O (x wt% Sn loading relative to rice husk) solution slowly dripped and stirring at 45 °C for 12 h. The solvent water was removed by using a rotary steam dryer and dried in an oven at 105 °C overnight. When the tube furnace was heated to 300 °C, the dried powder was added. Subsequently, the temperature was heated (1 °C /min) to the target temperature (600 °C if not specified) and maintained for 2 h. The entire pyrolysis process was carried out in a N2 flow (100 mL/min). After cooling to room temperature, the powder was purged with 1 % O2/N2 for 30 min. The obtained samples are named as xSn-5Co@RHC. The synthesis of 2Sn-5Co@RHC(Co(NO3)2) is also performed according to the method above, but CoCl2·6H2O is replaced by Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Similarly, SnCl4·5H2O is replaced by SnCl2·2H2O to obtain 3Sn-5Co@RHC(SnCl2). 5Co-3Sn@RHC preparation process is as follows: 5 g of rice husk (> 80 mesh) was added to a 50 mL aqueous solution containing 0.46 g of SnCl4·5H2O (3 wt% Sn loading relative to rice husk). After cooling down to room temperature, the mixture was transferred to a round-bottomed flask. 1.06 g of CoCl2·6H2O (5 wt% Co loading relative to rice husk) solution slowly dripped and stirring at 45 °C for 12 h. The Subsequent preparation process is the same as 3Sn-5Co@RHC. 3Sn-5Co/RHC is prepared by first co-impregnation of rice husk in a solution containing both SnCl4·5H2O and CoCl2·6H2O (the mass fractions of Sn and Co metal relative to rice husk are 3 wt% and 5 wt%, respectively). After drying, the subsequent processing process of the solid powder is the same as 3Sn-5Co@RHC. The preparation procedure for 3Sn-5Co@CC is the same as that for 3Sn-5Co@RHC, except that the rice husks are replaced with cellulose. Catalyst characterization The morphology of the catalyst was observed by LaB6 transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-1400FLASH, JEOL, Japan) and high-resolution field emission transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEM-2100F, JEOL, Japan). The structural properties of the catalyst were determined by a fully automatic specific surface and porosity analyzer (TriStarⅡ3020, Micromeritics, USA). Using a fixed target X-ray diffractometer (XRD, PANalytical X-Pert PRO MPD, B.V., Holland) and X-ray photoelectronic spectrometer (XPS, ESCALAB250Xi, Thermo, USA) to determine the phase composition and chemical state of the catalyst. The analysis of surface functional groups was carried out using a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FT-IR, Nicolet, Thermo, USA). Catalyst test Conversion of cellulose was carried out in a high-pressure autoclave (Anhui Kemi Machinery Technology Co., Ltd, 25 mL). Typically, 50 mg of cellulose, 50 mg of catalyst and 10 mL of deionized water were added to the autoclave. The sealed autoclave was charged and deflated with H2 several times before it was pressurized with H2 to 4 MPa at room temperature. With a magnetic stirrer, the reactor was heated to 250 °C for 1 hour. After the reaction system was cooled to room temperature, the reaction solution was filtered. The filtrate was analyzed in a high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Waters1525), equipped with a detector of ShodexRI-201H and a column of Bio-RadAminexHPX-87H(300 × 7.8 mm), 0.005 M H2SO4 aqueous solution was used as the mobile phase. The calculation formula of product yield is as follows: The yield of product = Masses of carbon in the product Masses of carbon in the cellulose added to the reactor Results and discussion Activity and characterization of catalysts A series of rice husk carbon supported Sn-Co bimetal catalysts were prepared by changing the metal loading method (impregnation or hydrothermal and metal loading sequence) as described in Scheme 2 . The activities of these catalysts show significant differences in the aqueous phase hydrogenolysis reaction of cellulose. As shown in Fig. 1 , using 3Sn-5Co/RHC prepared by conventional co-impregnation method (immersion in a mixed solution of SnCl4 and CoCl2, followed by pyrolysis) as the catalyst, 34.4 % yield of acetol, 9.4 % yield of 1‑hydroxy-2-butanone (HB) and 12.3 % yield of lactic acid (LA) can be obtained at 250 °C, 4 MPa H2 for 1 h. If the metal loading is adjusted to be hydrothermal pre-treatment in SnCl4 solution before impregnation in CoCl2 solution, the prepared 5Co-3Sn@RHC catalyst shows unsatisfactory catalytic activity, with only 28.1 % yield of acetol is obtained. However, if the metal loading sequence is reversed (3Sn-5Co@RHC), with hydrothermal treatment with CoCl2 and then impregnation with SnCl4, 50.7 % high yield of acetol, 10.2 % of HB and 12.7 % of LA are achieved, resulting in a total yield of 60.9 % for keto alcohol and 63.4 % for C3 products. As a comparison, if rice husks are replaced with cellulose without biogenic silica, the prepared 3Sn-5Co@CC catalyst shows the least desirable activity, yielding only 27.3 % of acetol with very small amounts of HB and LA. The above results indicate that biogenic silica in rice husk can promote the conversion of cellulose to acetol catalyzed by Co-Sn bimetallic catalyst, and the bimetallic loading method also significantly affects the catalytic activity, which may be related to the interaction between metal and rice husk carbon. To investigate the reasons for the changes of catalyst activity, a series of characterizations were carried out. XRD analysis was performed to study the phase composition of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 2 , the diffraction peaks at 41.3° and 48.1° of 3Sn-5Co/RHC are attributed to the Co3SnC0.7 (111) and (200) crystal planes, and the diffraction peaks at 44.2° and 51.5° are attributed to the Co (111) and (200). For 5Co-3Sn@RHC, the same diffraction peaks are observed, but the diffraction peaks of Co are stronger, indicating the formation of larger Co particles. Interestingly, when the metal loading sequence is reversed, two new peaks attributed to Co3Sn2 appear at 30.5° and 43.2° in the 3Sn-5Co@RHC catalyst, indicating that the metal loading method affects the interaction between metals and thus affects the phase composition of the catalysts. In addition, 3Sn-5Co@CC only shows strong Co diffraction peaks, no Co3Sn2 and Co3SnC0.7 are observed, indicating that biogenic silica has a promoting effect on the formation of alloys and intermetallic compounds. Combined with the cellulose transformation results in Fig. 1, the excellent catalytic performance of 3Sn-5Co@RHC could be related to the Co3Sn2 alloy formation. The valence state of Sn in the Co3Sn2 alloy is slightly positive (Snδ+) due to its small electronegativity (1.88 of Sn vs 1.96 of Co). Previous studies have shown that Snδ+ with slightly positive valence has excellent catalytic activity for retro-aldol condensation, which is essential for the conversion of fructose intermediates to C3 products [13,24]. The TEM images show that different preparation methods significantly affected the dispersion of metals. In general, metals disperse better on rice husk carbon (RHC)than cellulose carbon (CC) carrier, which is consistent with XRD results (Fig. 2). However, from the results of nitrogen adsorption and desorption (Table 1 ), the specific surface area (SSA) of catalysts prepared from rice husk is actually much lower than that prepared from cellulose. The SSA of rice husk-based catalysts is between 260 and 290 m2 /g, while 3Sn-5Co@CC reaches 481 m2/g. This indicates that although rice husk carbon has a low SSA, it can better attach with metal to a certain extent and inhibit sintering agglomeration. HRTEM of 3Sn-5Co@RHC found that lattice stripes of Co3Sn2(230), (311) and Co (200) surfaces are observed on a metal particle, indicating that two phases co-exist in a nanoparticle. EDS mapping shows that biogenic silica is uniformly dispersed in the carbon material, which was conducive to better dispersion of Co and Sn metals by enhancing the interaction between metals and biogenic silica. The chemical states of Co and Sn in catalysts were analyzed by XPS. The deconvolution of the Co2p regions is shown in Fig. 4a. The binding energies at around 797.5 eV and 781.6 eV are assigned to Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 of oxidized Co species, respectively [25,26]. According to the values of binding energy and the Co 2p1/2–2p3/2 spin orbit coupling (15.9 eV), the cobalt species on the 3Sn-5Co@CC surface should be attributed to Co2+(CoO), while the binding energy of Co3+ is around 795.3 eV and 780.3 eV, and its Co 2p1/2–2p3/2 spin orbit coupling value is 15 eV [27]. Interestingly, the Co 2p1/2–2p3/2 spin orbit coupling value increases when Co is loaded on RHC, reaching 16.0 eV, 16.1 eV and 16.4 eV in 5Co-3Sn@RHC, 3Sn-5Co/RHC and 3Sn-5Co@RHC, respectively. It is speculated that the increase in Co2p1/2–2p3/2 spin orbit coupling value could be attributed to the binding of Co2+ with biogenic silica [28]. 3Sn-5Co@RHC has the largest Co2p1/2–2p3/2 spin orbit coupling value implying a higher proportion of Co2+ binding. It indicates that high-temperature hydrothermal treatment of rice husks in CoCl2 solution significantly promotes the combination of Co2+ with silica, while impregnation loading is not conducive to the binding of the two. Fig. 4b shows the deconvolution of Sn3d regions. The binding energies at around 487.1 eV and 495.6 eV are attributed to 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 of Sn4+, respectively [29,30]. For the RHC-based catalysts, new peaks appear at 488.0 eV and 496.5 eV. According to previous research, it should be attributed to Sn-O-Si species [31]. In 5Co-3Sn@RHC, the Sn-O-Si species account for 77.3 % of the total Sn species, indicating that hydrothermal treatment in SnCl4 solution is beneficial to Sn4+ doping. The proportion of Sn-O-Si species in 3Sn-5Co/RHC prepared by the co-impregnation method reaches 74.1 %, which is only slightly lower than that in 5Co-3Sn@RHC, demonstrating that Sn4+ is easier to enter the silica framework than Co2+, because it has the same positive tetravalent as Si4+. However, if biogenic silica first binds to Co2+ under hydrothermal conditions, the doping of Sn4+ is inhibited, resulting in only 54.6 % of Sn-O-Si in 3Sn-5Co@RHC. Inconsistent with the XRD results, no metallic Co or Sn was detected in all catalysts, which is attributed to the oxidation of the surface metallic Co or Sn during passivation and exposure to air. FT-IR analysis was performed to demonstrate the interaction between the metal and silica. As shown in Fig. 5, the peaks at 1617 cm−1 and 3436 cm−1 observed in the RHC and 3Sn-5Co@RHC samples are attributed to the stretching vibrations of the hydroxyl groups in physically adsorbed H2O and SiOH [32,33]. The peaks at 1096 cm−1, 802 cm−1 and 463 cm−1 are attributed to the asymmetric, symmetric stretching vibrations and bending vibrations of the Si-O-Si bonds [34,35]. The characteristic peak of surface Si-OH centered at 965 cm−1 appears in the RHC but disappears in 3Sn-5Co@RHC, suggesting that Si-OH combines with Co2+ or Sn4+ to form silicates [36], which is consistent with the results of XPS. Based on the above analysis, the loading mode and sequence of the metal affect the structure of the catalyst to a great extent. Since Sn4+ has a similar ortho-tetravalent with Si4+ [37], both traditional impregnation and hydrothermal treatment in Sn4+ solution lead to strong interaction between Sn4+ and biogenic silica. Most of the Sn4+ effortlessly enters into the silica matrix to form the Sn-O-Si structure, with only a small portion of Sn4+ remaining to form an intermetallic compound of Co3SnC0.7 (Scheme 3 ,Ⅰ). After changing the sequence of metal loading, the biogenic silica in rice husk first binds with Co2+ under hydrothermal conditions to occupy a part of Si-OH site, which will inhibit the over-doping of Sn4+ to a certain extent in the subsequent treatment. The more sufficient remaining Sn4+ will combine with Co2+ to form Co3Sn2 as well as a part of Co3SnC0.7 under carbothermal reduction conditions (Scheme 3,Ⅱ). Cellulose conversion The carbothermal reduction temperature of catalyst significantly affects the bonding between metal and support and the sintering of metal particles, which in turn affects its catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 6a, when the pyrolysis temperature is 500 °C, only the Co metal diffraction peak is detected. With the increase of pyrolysis temperature, Co3Sn2 and Co3SnC0.7 gradually form, and the enhancement of the diffraction peak indicates the increase of metal particle size (Figure S1). These catalysts all exhibit good activity for cellulose conversion (Fig. 6b), while the catalysts containing Co3Sn2 seem to be more conducive to acetol formation, which is consistent with the results in Fig. 1. The effects of reaction temperature and hydrogen pressure were also studied. In general, a high temperature of >230 °C and hydrogen pressure of >3 MPa are conducive to the conversion of cellulose to acetol. The effects of the Sn/Co ratio and the type of metal precursor on cellulose conversion were investigated. As shown in Table 2 , when no Sn is added, 5Co@RHC (CoCl2 as precursor) catalyst can obtain 31 % yield of acetol, 8.4 % yield of HB and 6.7 % yield of LA. With the increase of Sn content, the yield of acetol gradually increases, and reaches the maximum value of 50.7 % when the Sn/Co ratio is 3/5. The yield of acetol decreases slightly with the further increase of the ratio. These results indicated that Co@RHC prepared with CoCl2 as the precursor has certain catalytic activities for carbohydrate isomerization, retro-aldol condensation and selective hydrogenation, and the addition of Sn further promoted the above reactions. When bivalent Sn2+ (SnCl2) is used as the Sn source, the prepared 3Sn-5Co@RHC(SnCl2) also shows good catalytic activity, and 48.8 % yield of acetol is achieved. Interestingly, if Co(NO3)2 is used as a precursor, no acetol or HB is produced, but small amounts of the over-hydrogenated products 1,2-propylene glycol and 1,2-butanediol are produced. This indicates that Co@RHC(Co(NO3)2) has better hydrogenation activity, which is adverse to acetol generation. When Sn is added, the catalytic property of 2Sn-5Co@RHC(Co(NO3)2) is similar to the 2Sn-5Co@RHC prepared by CoCl2. The conversion of cellulose to acetol requires a delicate balance between hydrogenation, isomerization, and retro-aldol condensation reactions of the intermediates, which are well regulated by the addition of Sn. Intermediates study In order to investigate the reaction behavior of the intermediates catalyzed by 3Sn-5Co@RHC, the conversion of glucose and fructose at different temperatures and concentrations was investigated. As shown in Fig. 7a, under the reaction conditions that are suitable for cellulose conversion (5 mg/mL of substrate, 250 °C or 240 °C), only <40 % yield of acetol is obtained when glucose is used as substrate. Other products are mainly small amounts of HB and LA (not listed in the figure). Decreasing the reaction temperature is beneficial to the formation of acetol, and the yield reaches 50 % at 180 °C for 1 h. Extending the reaction time to 6 h did not result in a significant change in the yield of acetol (48.8 %), indicating that a reaction time of 1 h was sufficient despite the reduced reaction temperature. When fructose is used as the substrate, the same trend with lower acetol yield is obtained. It implies that at 250 °C, glucose is easily polymerized to produce humins or other undetectable molecules. The higher yield of acetol obtained using cellulose as substrate could be attributed to the gradual release of glucose from cellulose hydrolysis. To verify this point, the conversion of glucose with different concentrations was carried out. As shown in Fig. 7c, with the glucose concentration gradually decreasing from 5 mg/mL to 1 mg/L, the yield of acetol increases from 39.4 % to 72.6 %. When fructose is used as the substrate, the yield of acetol increases from 39.7 % to 64.8 % with decreasing concentration. The results show that the lower concentration of glucose and fructose intermediates is conducive to inhibiting the side reactions and improving the selectivity of acetol. Comparing the cellulose conversion results (50.7 % yield of acetol), 3Sn-5Co@RHC seems to be able to control the monosaccharide concentration below 4 mg/mL in the cellulose hydrothermal system (Fig. 3 ). Based on the above results, the catalytic mechanism is proposed (Scheme 4 ). In the non-acidic water phase reaction system, cellulose gradually hydrolyzes to glucose. Since 3Sn-5Co@RHC prepared by the strategy of hydrothermal treatment in CoCl2 solution followed by impregnation with Sn4+ is conducive to forming suitable Sn-O-Si and Co3Sn2 sites, the glucose then isomerizes to form fructose at the Sn-O-Si site (biogenic silica doped with Sn site) [38]. The generated fructose undergoes retro-aldol condensation at the Co3Sn2 site to form C3 intermediates, which are then converted into acetol through dehydration and hemi-hydrogenation. 3Sn-5Co@RHC can provide cellulose with an appropriate hydrolysis rate, inhibit the accumulation of glucose and fructose, and achieve a good match for the conversion of various intermediates, thereby selectively generating acetol. Conclusion In this work, a series of Sn-Co bimetallic catalysts were prepared by using rice husks with abundant biogenic silica as carrier precursors. It is found that the metal loading mode and sequence can significantly affect the phase composition of the catalysts and thereby affecting catalytic activity for cellulose conversion. Hydrothermal treatment of rice husks in CoCl2 solution, followed by impregnation with Sn4+, facilitates the binding of biogenic silica with Co2+, inhibits the excessive incorporation of Sn4+into the silica matrix, and promotes the formation of Co3Sn2 active phase. The prepared 3Sn-5Co@RHC shows good catalytic performance, and a 50.7 % yield of acetol can be obtained. Conversely, the opposite metal-loading sequence or conventional co-impregnation methods lead to excessive doping of Sn4+, forming Co3SnC0.7 intermetallic compounds. A series of comparative analysis and intermediates experiments show that suitable Sn-O-Si doping site and Co3Sn2 site can effectively catalyze the isomerization of glucose and the retro-aldol condensation of fructose, and avoid the accumulation of monosaccharides and the occurrence of side reactions. This work can provide guidance for the construction of rice husk-based catalysts with excellent catalytic performance and the preparation of acetol from cellulose, promoting the high-value utilization of renewable biomass resources. coredata.dc:description: The production of high value-added chemicals and materials from renewable biomass is significant for the sustainable development of chemical industry. Herein, rice husk-based biogenic silica-anchored Sn-Co catalysts with adjustable activity are successfully prepared for biomass valorization. By regulating the pretreatment method and carbothermal reduction temperature of catalysts, the interaction between Co, Sn and biogenic silica can be regulated, thereby regulating the catalytic activity of the catalyst for cellulose hydrogenolysis. 50.7 % yield of acetol and 63.4 % yield of C3 products can be obtained. A series of characterizations show that the hydrothermal pretreatment in CoCl2 solution promotes the combination of Co2+ and biogenic silica, which inhibits the excessive doping of Sn4+ and promotes the formation of Co3Sn2 alloy. The Sn-O-Si and Co3Sn2 species in 3Sn-5Co@RHC are the key active sites catalyzing glucose isomerization and fructose retro-aldol condensation. The intermediates experiments show that controlling the hydrolysis rate of cellulose to avoid excessive concentration of monosaccharide intermediates in the reaction system is crucial for inhibiting side reactions and improving the yield of acetol. The use of agroforestry waste-based catalytic materials for biomass conversion in this work can provide inspiration for exploiting the intrinsic characteristics of biomass to develop high value-added materials and chemicals.
coredata.dc:title: Rice husk-based biogenic silica-anchored Sn-Co bimetallic catalysts for cellulose hydrogenolysis: Structural regulation and mechanism study
